instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were implemented for marine litter detection?

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the marine litter detection capability, and what were the metric achieved?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the marine litter detection capability was precision and recall. The precision rate of detection achieved was 70-80% for all three targets, compared to ground-truth pixels. The recall rates achieved were over 50%.

instruction: How were the machine learning methods utilized in the development of the remote hyperspectral imaging system for marine litter detection?
Output: The machine learning methods, namely Random Forest (RF) and Support Vector Machines (SVM), were implemented in the development of the remote hyperspectral imaging system for marine litter detection. These methods were used for marine litter artificial target detection based on previous training. The system utilized the spatial and spectral response data obtained from the in-situ characterization of marine litter samples in the laboratory environment, as well as the remote observation data acquired during the dataset flights. The RF and SVM algorithms were trained using these datasets to detect marine litter concentrations in an oceanic environment. The obtained results showed a marine litter automated detection capability with a precision rate of 70-80% in all three targets, compared to ground-truth pixels, as well as recall rates over 50%.

instruction: How does the precision rate of the developed remote hyperspectral imaging system for detecting marine litter compare to traditional methods?
Output: The precision rate of the developed remote hyperspectral imaging system for detecting marine litter is comparable to traditional methods.
